questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the dermatology OPD with findings as shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs can result in this adverse effect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Amantadine The above presentation is of livedo reticularis, which is an adverse effect of amantadine. The patient presents with a common skin finding consisting of a mottled vesicular pattern that appears as a lace-like or net-like purplish discoloration of the skin which is due to the local release of catecholamines resulting in post-capillary vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with painless hematuria. He has a history of travel to Kenya. Urine microscopy revealed the finding shown below. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Praziquantel The clinical scenario and the image showing the egg of Schistosoma hematobium (egg with terminal spine), point towards the diagnosis of schistosomiasis. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis caused by all Schistosoma species that can infect humans. A single oral dose of 40 mg/kg or three doses of 20 mg/kg each, given 4-6 h apart, generally produce cure rates of 70%-95% and consistently high reductions (>85%) in egg counts.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Liposomal amphotericin B The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis. Among the azole antifungal agents Isavuconazole and Posaconazole are useful against mucarmycosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for a patient presenting with the finding shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ivermectin This image shows a serpiginous, erythematous, raised lesion on the skin, characteristic of Cutaneous Larva Migrans, also known as "Creeping Eruption." Ivermectin is the first-line drug for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with fever with chills and seizures. On examination, his blood pressure was 70/50 mm of Hg and labored breathing was present. Routine blood investigations revealed Hb of 4.8 g/dl. ABG was done and the pH was 7.21. Findings in peripheral blood smear are shown below. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Artesunate This scenario depicts a case of severe complicated falciparum malaria, and the drug of choice in this condition is artesunate. The image shows ring forms/early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) and this is characteristic of P. falciparum malaria. Severe complicated malaria is caused by P. falciparum and is characterized by hyperparasitemia, hyperpyrexia, acidosis, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse, renal failure and cerebral malaria.

questions.text: Patient who is on anti-glaucoma therapy presents with corneal findings as shown in the image below. This finding is most commonly observed with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Netarsudil The bilateral whorl-like pattern of cream-colored lines on the cornea seen in the image is called cornea verticillata or vortex keratopathy. It is observed with the use of netarsudil It is usually mild and reversible and not associated with any significant visual abnormalities.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of lower backache. The MRI of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured, and her T-score is -2.8. She is given oral drugs, but she develops esophagitis. Which of the following intravenous treatment plans would be useful in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Zoledronate 5 mg annually The given x-ray depicts the ballooning of disc spaces, leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body, which is known as the ‘codfish’ appearance. Along with a T-score of -2.8, it is diagnostic of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Zoledronate 5 mg intravenous annually is used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. It belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates.

questions.text: Patient presented with palpitations and light-headedness. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lidocaine The given scenario and the ECG findings (rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline) point towards a diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Lidocaine use is unlikely to cause this condition, Lidocaine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmics.

questions.text: A young man working at a dairy farm presents with fever and abdominal pain. Examination of his stool samples revealed the finding shown in the image. Which of the following benzimidazoles is indicated in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Triclabendazole The given image showing operculated egg (egg having a lid- like structure on its end) is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica and the benzimidazole indicated for infection with this organism is triclabendazole.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset fever with chills and malaise. On examination splenomegaly was present. Bone marrow picture is shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hydroxychloroquine The given scenario and the bone marrow picture showing macrophages infected with intracellular Leishman- Donovan bodies point towards a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis. Hydroxychloroquine is not indicated in the treatment of this condition.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient presents with the following lesion on his right leg which has been present for the last 7 days. He is on medication for hypertension and diabetes for the past 10 years. He is a known epileptic on treatment and also frequently takes painkillers for osteoarthritis of both knees. The patient gives a history of similar lesions on the same site over the past few years which resolve spontaneously after 7-10 days. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ibuprofen This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen. Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to the hospital by her mother with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. Examination revealed a palpable abdominal mass. Investigations showed elevated levels of urinary homovanillic acid and vanillyl mandelic acid. The lesion could not be completely resected during surgery and histopathology findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody approved for use in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dinutuximab The given scenario and the histopathology (image) showing small round blue tumor cells with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes, point towards a diagnosis of paediatric neuroblastoma. Dinutuximab is the monoclonal antibody against glycolipid GD2 which is indicated in this condition. GD2 glycolipid is expressed on neuroblastoma cells and on normal cells of neuroectodermal origin, including the central nervous system and peripheral nerves

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy, the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is used as a first line management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The skull X-ray shows punched-out lytic lesions, a hallmark radiological finding of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH). The clinical presentation of pallor and lymphadenopathy further supports this diagnosis. • Vinblastine is the first-line drug used for the treatment of LCH, typically in combination with Prednisone. • This combination is the standard regimen for both single-system multifocal and multisystem LCH.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the medicine ward and you notice the given dermatological finding in a patient with abdominal distension. Which of the following hormones is implicated in this finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Estrogen The image shown is of spider nevus and the hormone Implicated in its development is estrogen. It is commonly seen in hyperestrogenic states such as pregnancy and in those taking estrogen-containing contraceptives. It can also be seen in male patients with cirrhosis due to the decreased ability of the liver to metabolize circulating estrogens, specifically estrone, which derives from the androgen androstenedione. Estrogens cause blood vessels to enlarge and dilate.

questions.text: The MRI of a patient who presented with new-onset seizures is shown below. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Albendazole The MRI findings (multiple cysticerci within the brain) are suggestive of neurocysticercosis and albendazole is the drug of choice in this condition. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole and continued for several days after the commencement of therapy. It reduces the inflammatory reaction to the dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with fatigue and weight loss. On examination, pallor and splenomegaly were noted. Peripheral blood smear examination findings are shown in the image. Which of the following BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors is not a first-line agent for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bosutinib The given scenario and the peripheral smear findings (increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms), is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Bosutinib is approved for use in this condition only for resistant and/or intolerant cases and not in newly diagnosed cases.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the above condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Warfarin The clinical scenario of the development of purple toe syndrome, after starting a new drug for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, is suggestive of the adverse effect of warfarin. Purple toe syndrome is a rare complication of warfarin therapy. It occurs due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion. Warfarin must be immediately stopped and replaced with an oral factor Xa inhibitor (e.g. apixaban).

questions.text: An infant is born with a birth defect as shown in the image below. It is the most common teratogenic effect of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sodium valproate The above illustration is suggestive of an infant with spina bifida of the open type which is the most common teratogenic effect of sodium valproate.

choices.text: Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old sexually active male presents to the clinic with complaints of purulent urethral discharge and burning sensation during urination for the past 3 days. He denies systemic symptoms such as fever but admits to multiple unprotected sexual encounters. A Gram stain of the urethral discharge shown in the image below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly single dose The image shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci, which are characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea. • Diagnosis: Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. • Treatment Guidelines (CDC, WHO): o First-line: Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscularly as a single dose. o For co-treatment of possible Chlamydia trachomatis coinfection: Add Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 7 days.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of epilepsy presents to the clinic with complaints of swollen, enlarged gums that bleed occasionally during brushing. On examination, his gums appear thickened, fibrotic, and inflamed, as shown in the image below. The patient’s mother reports that he has been on long-term medication to control his seizures but denies any other significant medical history. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the patient’s condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The clinical presentation and image depict gingival hypertrophy (gingival overgrowth), which is a well-known adverse effect of Phenytoin, a commonly used anticonvulsant for epilepsy.
